title: Functional Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I have had hearing loss and a constant tinnitus in my left ear for over 10 years. It sounds like a 'wind noise or low hum'.

problem_summary.laterality: Left ear reported; Right ear asymptomatic.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant tinnitus (left ear). Denies otalgia, otorrhea, or dizziness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient reports difficulty hearing in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking initial audiological examination after previous medical consult 10 years ago yielded no intervention.

history.present_illness: 63-year-old male presenting for initial exam. Reports 10-year history of LE hearing loss and tinnitus.
history.otologic_history: Consulted physician at onset 10 years ago; no intervention recommended. No history of ear pain or drainage.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Slight hearing loss at 250 Hz and 3000-8000 Hz; normal at 500-2000 Hz. Left ear: Moderately severe mixed hearing loss (flat configuration) indicated by thresholds, but validity is questionable due to inconsistencies.

numeric_results.RE_AC_thresholds: Normal 500-2000 Hz, dips to ~25-30 dB at 4k/8k Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear SRT is elevated compared to pure tone average (poor agreement). Left ear SRT agrees with the voluntary PTA but WRS is very poor.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A), which contradicts the air-bone gap seen in the Left Ear pure-tone thresholds.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal ipsilateral reflexes present at 500-1000 Hz bilaterally. The presence of reflexes in the Left Ear is physiologically inconsistent with the degree of mixed/conductive loss presented on the audiogram.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Pure-tone Stenger test was negative at 500 and 1000 Hz.

history.present_illness: Patient referred for objective testing (ABR and ASSR) due to fair test reliability and asymmetrical hearing loss in initial evaluation.

tests.name: Auditory Steady-State Response (ASSR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Hearing within normal limits. Left ear: Mild to moderate hearing loss at 250 to 2000 Hz.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Wave V peaks identified at 40 dB nHL bilaterally, indicating no more than a mild hearing loss in either ear between 2000 and 4000 Hz.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a voluntary audiogram suggesting unilateral moderately severe mixed hearing loss in the left ear. However, significant internal inconsistencies suggest functional (non-organic) hearing loss. Specifically, the presence of normal ipsilateral acoustic reflexes and Type A tympanograms in the left ear contradicts the voluntary display of a mixed loss with a conductive component. Additionally, the Right Ear SRT is elevated relative to the pure-tone average.
counseling_points: I am seeing some inconsistencies in the test results today that we need to clarify.
Your muscle reflex tests show your ears are responding to sound differently than your hand-raising responses suggest.
I would like to reinstruct you on the procedure and try the test again to ensure we get the most accurate picture of your hearing.
If the results remain unclear, we may need to use objective tests that do not require you to respond actively.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is consistent in their story but inconsistent in their test behavior.
You do not need to be hostile; you can be cooperative but simply 'unable' to hear the tones until they are loud.
If the audiologist challenges you gently, you can express confusion rather than anger.
